chapter.title: &dcache; Webadmin-Interface
chapter.para: This part describes how to configure the &cell-webadmin;-interface which is a replacement for the old &cell-httpd;-service and offers additional features to act as an adminservice to admins.

The &cell-webadmin;-interface uses a Jetty-Server which is embedded in an odinary &dcache;-cell. It is using apache-wicket (a webfrontend-framework) and YAML (a CSS-Template Framework). The application is wired up by a Spring IOC-Container. It receives the information from &dcache; infoservice as &xml; which are parsed and presented. For authentication and authorisation it offers usage of username/password(currently KAuth-File) or the grid-certificate talking to &cell-gplazma;. It also offers a non-authenticated, read-only mode.
If you are logged in as admin it is possible to send a command to multiple pools or a whole poolgroup in one go. It is even possible to send a command to any &dcache;-Cell.

section.title: Installation
section.para: To enable your &dcache; to run the &cell-webadmin;-interface your system has to run the &cell-info; service. For the authenticated mode a configured &cell-gplazma; is also required. The KAuth-File has to be on the same machine then the &cell-webadmin; for this to work. For a non-authenticated &cell-webadmin; you just need to give the &cell-webadmin; service to a domain and maybe configure the port &cell-webadmin; will listen on webadminHttpPort.

For authenticated mode a host certificate has to be imported into the &dcache;-keystore. In the grid world host certificates are usually signed by national Grid-CAs. Refer to the documentation provided by the Grid-CA to find out how to request a certificate. To import them into the &dcache;-keystore use this command: &prompt-root; /opt/d-cache/bin/dcache import hostcert Now you have to initialise your truststore (this is the certificate-store used for the SSL connections) by using this command: &prompt-root; /opt/d-cache/bin/dcache import cacerts Webadmin-interface uses the same truststore as &cell-webDAV;, so maybe you can skip this step.

You can enable the &cell-webadmin; interface by adding the service (&cell-webadmin;) to a domain; for example: [webadminDomain] [webadminDomain/webadmin] webadminHttpsPort=8443 webadminHttpPort=8080 webadminDCacheInstanceName=coolName webadminAuthenticated=true webadminAdminGid=1000

The most important value is webadminAdminGid, because it configures who is allowed to alter dCache behaviour, which certainly should not be everyone: # ---- GID a user has to have to be considered an Admin of webadmininterface # # When a user has this GID he can become an Admin for webadmininterface webadminAdminGid=1000 To see all webadmin specific property values have a look at ${dcache.home}/share/defaults/webadmin.properties
For information on &cell-gplazma; configuration have a look at and for a special example .
After startup of webadmin you can reach it via http://example.com:8080/webadmin. Since webadmin bases on the &cell-info; it takes some time until all values are populated, because &cell-info; needs to collect them first. We are working on making this process faster in future releases. It is recommended to let &cell-info; run on the same machine then &cell-webadmin;.
